content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Love the concept and the end result

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I enjoyed this contribution very much.
Of course "easy to play hard to master".

I hope to see this contribution soon in multi !

Bob,
is it possible to change the images of the forests or the grasslands ? because they are visually very close

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is fun. Easy to have a working bot, hard to have a winning bot.

Bob, your game is a bit scary at first sight : many inputs and the rules are not so clear till you haven't given a try. But at the end the game is funny. The graphic interface is very pleasant. As it is the stub code won't work for every configuration, but I have been able to adapt, so other people will work this out as well.
So I am very pleased to approve your contribution.

Bob,
J'ai l'esprit mal placé ou je vois quelque chose que je ne devrais pas voir dans ton blason ?
;-)
Default code doesn't work in C# `nbLines` doesn't exist. Think you can set this to 9 in the stub.

Not sure if this is specific to this game, but the viewer does not seem to work in Firefox? (Update: seems like I haven't played any MP recently, same problem for all other games. Will check the forum.)
1v1 variant here: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/48402c32450ea84b38bab017cba64246a49a

Inputs:
- E : The maximum extent of the grid. Isn't it the maximum extent of a territory ?
Stub:
- gridSize : The maximum allowed extension of your land. So why gridSize ?

Inputs:
 - the ID of a tile being placed that turn
 - the tile you are placing this turn
The second part is inculded in the first one, is it necessary?

The grid input format is quite awkward: the problem is that the limits of the players' territories are not known and may change in all directions until late in the game, yet I still have to keep a fixed reference point for outputting the tile location. This is why I'm using an oversized grid that can accommodate full extension in all four directions, with the castle in the center.

If anyone can think of something better...?
What about a list of coord (x,y) from the castle ?

It's for two player mode, because you have two tiles with your own playerId during one round and you need to know which one you are playing.

It's necessary to give all four tiles, including the ones that have already been played, otherwise in four player mode, depending on the order of play you might not be able to tell who picked what.
Um yeah awkward indeed. I have modified the names of the variables to match their meaning and be consistent between the statement and stub.

I have seen this mentioned in the chat, it's not specific to this game, it's a known issue with some recent versions of Firefox and there's a simple workaround for it.
Maybe check the forum, in all probability it has been posted there.

My bad - that changed just recently (2-player had a different number of lines one week ago)  and since all beta testers already had working code by that time, it went unnoticed.

This is now fixed, along with the tiles loop which systematically read 4 tiles instead of nbTiles (and was hence incorrect for 3 players).

Thanks.
Tu as l'esprit mal placé et c'est même pas moi qui l'ai fait :p

Thanks :)  Do give a try to the 1v1 version too ;)

I agree the rules can be somewhat confusing until you get to actually play the game. 
The core system is actually quite simple and very smooth but indeed a bit awkward to formulate.
I have uploaded a version with lighter grass tiles, it should be better now.
Thanks :)

Ok.
In two players mode it seems that put command chose tile with min(id) first?

Yes, it's really the core of the game logic: tiles are always played in ascending ID order. This guarantees that a player who picks a low tile on turn N plays earlier on turn N+1 and gets more opportunities to pick higher tiles.
Conversely a player who picks a high tile on turn N will play later on turn N + 1 and gets a more restricted choice because other players will have picked first.
So players need to balance between getting the tiles they need, preventing others from getting tiles they need and securing play order to avoid getting crappy leftovers.

After live chat with Vry - his question was whether it would make more sense to play in pick order rather than ID order for 2 players (e.g. if you pick 43 then 3, you'd play 43 then 3 instead of 3 then 43).
The original rules state ID order. For 3 and 4 players there is no other choice since each player only has one tile to play, so it's simpler to also use ID order for 2 players rather than make a particular case.

Also, using pick order for 2 players would just determine the order in which one player carries out his two turns, but not the order of play between players, so it would mean adding another rule for that. ID order determines both in one go.

Note that ID order is important because placing the first tile may potentially prevent you from placing the second one, forcing you to discard it, so you have to take that in consideration when picking for 2 players.
Update: I have modified the input format for the current tiles, now with an extra 1/0 flag indicating the current tile, and removed the duplication of current tile.
A list of squares with coordinates could work I guess, but I'd rather not introduce negative coordinates.
